summary: acute respiratory infections are among the leading causes of disease and mortality in developing and developed countries. seasonal influenza epidemics attack 10–20% of the human population, leading to 290–650 thousand deaths/year worldwide each year. the world is confronted every 10–40 years with newly emerging influenza A virus infections. despite significant efforts to develop a safe and effective vaccine, there are no approved vaccines for MERS-CoV until now. genetically and phenotypically stable vaccines represent a promising alternative to control IAV and MERS-CoV infections. an Egyptian MERS-CoV isolate was obtained from the virus collection of Center of Scientific excellence for Influenza Viruses. the two viruses were used for preparation of the OMVs-based dual vaccine and inactivated vaccines were used as positive control. the plasmid pMP-HA-Gi [21] encoding the HA of Cal-H1N1pdm2009 was used as template DNA for F1 and F3. the plasmid pcDNA3.1-Spike-MERS-CoV encoding the spike protein from the isolate MERS-CoV/Camel/Egypt/HKU-NRCE-270/2013 was used as a template for F2.
